channel.title: Limewire is shut down
channel.description:
LimeWire, one of the world's most popular peer-to-peer filesharing websites, has been shut down after a four-year legal battle with the US music industry. A federal court in New York issued a "permanent injunction" against LimeWire late on Tuesday, ruling that the platform intentionally caused a "massive scale of infringement" by permitting the sharing of thousands of copyrighted works by its 50 million monthly users. Founded in 2000 by Mark Gorton, a former Wall Street trader, LimeWire is now restricted from allowing the searching and sharing of copyrighted material. The website will continue "working with the music industry to move forward", a LimeWire spokeswoman confirmed. US judge Kimba Wood ruled that record companies "have suffered – and will continue to suffer – irreparable harm from LimeWire's inducement of widespread infringement of their works", adding that the potential damages were "staggering". The court also ruled that LimeWire should "use all reasonable technological means to immediately cease and desist" copyright infringements still taking place through applications already downloaded. Yesterday's court order comes after a four-year legal battle between LimeWire and the Recording Industry Association of America, the representative body for many of the world's largest record labels. In May, Wood found LimeWire liable for widespread copyright infringement. The level of damages faced by the site's New York-based parent company, Lime Group, will be decided in January 2011. The RIAA said LimeWire has cost the music industry hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue. According RIAA figures, US recorded music sales fell to $7.7bn in 2009 from $14.5bn in 1999. The rise to prominence of peer-to-peer filesharing networks is singled out as a primary factor for this decline by the RIAA. The site's popularity is reflected in a survey by NDP Group, which found that LimeWire was used by 58% of people who have downloaded music from a peer-to-peer network in the year from May 2009. Following Tuesday's injunction, the RIAA said: "For the better part of the last decade, LimeWire and Gorton have violated the law. "The court has now signed an injunction that will start to unwind the massive piracy machine that LimeWire and Gorton used to enrich themselves immensely. "In January, the court will conduct a trial to determine the appropriate level of damages necessary to compensate the record companies for the billions and billions of illegal downloads that occurred through the LimeWire system." Earlier this year, LimeWire planned to release a service called Spoon, which would allow users to legally purchase copyrighted tracks. The deal fell through, however, when record labels were told that the site would need at least a year to migrate illicit filesharers to the new service. Napster, which claimed more than 100 million users at the height of its popularity at the beginning of the decade, collapsed in 2002 under the strain of a number of legal challenges. The company reinvented itself as a legal download service in 2004, later launching what it claimed was "the world's largest and most comprehensive MP3 store", before unveiling a "freemium" model – similar to that of Spotify – last year.
sause: http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2010/oct/27/limewire-shut-down Check out the [url=http://www.limewire.com]limewire website[/url] for lulz. It wont make much of a difference to normal people but to morons that actually use limewire will be really pissed off at this news. Personally i'm glad that it's been shut down since the gnutella is such a shit network.

item.title: Limewire is shut down
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:31, topic:366203”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=462407.msg3390904#msg3390904 date=1288911423]

The argument was that although the purpose of Limewire had good intentions, the majority of its users were using it for pirating etc.

That’s not the same with automobiles though, because the majority of the population isn’t using a car to break the law.

Aren’t they? I don’t know any driver that hasn’t at least went 5mph over the speed limit. That means that 100% of automobiles are used to break the law. Sue the manufacturers!!!

5mph isnt an illegal amount to go over the speed limit, afaik its 10%+3 for the limit before you can be fined speeding,

You might get by with it, but it is still illegal. You also might get by with downloading a song or two that you don’t have rights to, but that is still illegal as well.

no as in if the police catch you doing 10%+3 they cannot give you a speeding ticket, they cant. whereas they could fine you for downloading a song
[/quote]

Might be different where you live, but here if the police want to give you a ticket for going 5 over, then they can.[/quote]
Yep. And there radar detectors are accurate.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

Radars only read increments of 5 or something, that is why you don’t get in trouble for 5 - 9 over. Most if the time it’s not possible to prove 6 to 9 mph over. Anything over the given limit on signs is illegal though.

The fact that Limewire is gone now, just means people will turn to alternate ways of acquiring free copyrighted material. Which means other file sharing sites will suffer as well. If anything, they’re going to go after torrent sites even more now.

item.title: Limewire is shut down
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:366203”]I love open source programs running distributed networking protocols that don’t rely on any central server that could be shut down.

Consider two arguments:

[ol][li]People break the law with a perfectly legal program and the author of that program is sued and blamed for it?[/li]
[li]
Can the government sue the auto industry for drug trafficking? Most drug trafficking is done with some type of vehicle, certainly the auto industry is to blame, right?[/li][/ol]

Aren’t both arguments equivalent? If number 1 holds then shouldn’t number 2?[/quote]
Everyone knows Limewire is heavily connected to music downloaders, but they played the SCAR card. I dont think limewire has ever said the software was created specifically for music.

Read full topic
